review.title: Almost Optimal Intervention Sets for Causal Discovery
review.abstract: We conjecture that the worst case number of experiments necessary and sufficient to discover a causal graph uniquely given its observational Markov equivalence class can be specified as a function of the largest clique in the Markov equivalence class. We provide an algorithm that computes intervention sets that we believe are optimal for the above task. The algorithm builds on insights gained from the worst case analysis in Eberhardt et al. (2005) for sequences of experiments when all possible directed acyclic graphs over N variables are considered. A simulation suggests that our conjecture is correct. We also show that a generalization of our conjecture to other classes of possible graph hypotheses cannot be given easily, and in what sense the algorithm is then no longer optimal.

metadata.title: Almost Optimal Intervention Sets for Causal Discovery

sections.text: We suspect that the worst possible number of experiments, which are necessary and sufficient to discover a causal graph that is unique due to its observational Markov equivalence class, can be specified as a function of the largest clique in the Markov equivalence class. We provide an algorithm that calculates intervention sets that we believe are optimal for the above task. The algorithm builds on insights gained from the worst-case analysis in Eberhardt et al. (2005) for experiment sequences in which all possible steered acyclic graphs via N variables are considered. A simulation suggests that our assumption is correct. We also show that a generalization of our assumption to other classes of possible graph hypotheses cannot simply be given, and in which sense the algorithm is then no longer optimal.

sections.heading: 1.1 BACKGROUND
sections.text: Traditionally, causal discovery algorithms have been divided into two categories: Constraint based and Score based algorithms. Score based algorithms, such as the GESalgorithm (Chickering 2002), calculate a score for each model taking into account the measured data. The model with the highest score is then considered the most likely or plausible model taking into account the data. In contrast, constraint based algorithms (e.g. the PC algorithm (Spirtes et al. 2000) are tested for certain constraints in the measured data and models that correspond to the detected constraints are selected. Independence constraints are most often used, but many other constraints can also be factored.Without further assumptions (such as time order, non-Gaussian errors, etc.), both types of search algorithms are asymptotically limited to the discovery of OMEs or MMEs of causal structures.

sections.heading: 4 SIMULATION
sections.text: Knowing that the guesses do not apply to general knowledge, and that we have reason to believe that this applies to OMEs, we tested the guesses in a simulation. Since the space of DAGs is very exponential, we are dealing with a number of variables for which there is no obvious clue as to how to generate a reasonable graph that is very similar (and indeed quite small). Also, if we just randomly select from the space of all possible variables, we get a sample of graphs that are very similar.

sections.heading: 5 DISCUSSION
sections.text: The difficulty in specifying a certain number of experiments given to an OME when only individual (or very few) interventions are allowed per experiment is due to the interdependence of two adjacent edges. For example, if we know from passive observation that the OME is a chain of undirected edges, we know that this chain cannot contain vstructures, since it could contain a common cause in any vertex (except the ends).

sections.heading: 6 CONCLUSION
sections.text: We have provided an algorithm for calculating intervention sets based on the qualitative structural limitations of hypotheses spaces, which can be represented by knowledge diagrams. Knowledge diagrams provide a concise representation of hypotheses that characterize the underdetermination of causal structures from passive observation data (observing Markov equivalence classes) and subdeterminations based on experiment sequences. We suspect that the number of experiments that are sufficient and, at worst, necessary to discover the true causal structure in an OME is a function of the largest undirected clique in the OME, and we have shown why this assumption cannot be generalized to all knowledge diagrams. In simulations, we have shown that our OPTINTER algorithm determines intervention sets that generate experiment sequences that satisfy the assumption. As a result, we have a search method that is adaptive and therefore much more efficient than the number of experiments that are actually (the) the worst in the case.
